description: From Middle English peritot, from Anglo-Norman peridou, peridout, Middle French perido, peridon, of uncertain origin; later reborrowed from modern French p√©ridot.

entries.meaning: A transparent olive-green form of olivine, used as a gem.
examples: Gem-quality olivine is known as peridot, which has a subtle green light all its own.

entries.meaning: A yellow-green colour, like that of the peridot.
